Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube IA: Collaborative Proposal: Building Interoperable Cyberinfrastructure (CI) at the Interface between Paleogeoinformatics and Bioinformatics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Paleontologists provide data about the past distribution and diversity of life. These data are useful both to geologists, because they can help determine the age of rocks, reconstruct past environments, and constrain models of the Earth system; and to biologists interested in the evolutionary history of organisms and the behavior of ecological systems during past global changes. Currently, data about fossils are dispersed across thousands of scientific publications, and dozens of small to large databases, only some of which are publicly available via the Internet. Even publicly available databases can be difficult to access because each stores different kinds of data with different conventions, requiring researchers to individually harmonize searches and their outputs. This project brings together six paleobiological databases so that they share a single set of Internet-based commands by which researchers and the public can easily access fossil records from all of Earth history. By coordinating with other emerging efforts in geological and biological data sharing, best practices, and protocols, we ensure that data will be freely available to all, enabling new scientific syntheses and discovery, more powerful educational opportunities, and general exploration of the history of life on Earth.

The paleobiological sciences sit at the nexus between geosciences and the biosciences, with close interdependencies in both domains. Within the geosciences, information about the past spatiotemporal distribution of organisms, species, and assemblages of species is essential to a wide array of allied disciplines: to sedimentologists and economic geologists studying facies relationships and employing biostratigraphic controls for correlating rock strata, to structural geologists and geophysicists seeking biogeographic constraints on reconstructions of former tectonic plate positions, to paleoclimatologists extracting paleoclimatic signals from paleoecological data, and to earth system modelers seeking to understand how biospheric dynamics have shaped, and continue to shape, the history of the Earth-Life system. Within the biosciences, the fossil record is essential for understanding how contemporary ecological systems are shaped by historical legacies of slow-acting processes, for testing climate-driven models of species distribution and diversity that are being used to project the impacts of 21st century climate change, for constraining phylogenetic models of species divergence and rates of evolution, and for understanding the fundamental drivers of biodiversity (i.e. species extinctions and originations). In an era of global change, when stewarding biodiversity is an urgent societal concern, conservation biologists, global change ecologists, and earth system scientists are all looking to the past to study the behavior of the Earth-Life system during rapid transitions. Paleobiological data are currently served by a wide array of databases that vary in structure, composition, temporal scales, types of data and metadata. To conduct ?global? or holistic analyses of the paleobiological record it is necessary to retrieve data from a variety of these databases - requiring queries of each database to retrieve the types of data needed. The purpose of this project is to make six different paleobiological databases interoperable so that they can be accessed via a common Application Programming Interface (API) to query the data from these and other databases. Towards that end, five key records of North American Pleistocene lakes will be uploaded and become available through this integrative project. This project also will increase the interoperability between these paleobiological resources and contemporary databases of species distributions and diversity, enabling continuous time-series analyses (e.g., of biodiversity) from the beginning of life on earth to today. Integration of the paleobiological databases with databases of the stratigraphic record (Macrostrat) will enhance the value of both types of data. New R packages will facilitate retrieval and analysis of data from all of the databases. Finally, this proposal establishes a Paleobiological Data Consortium, consisting of leaders of cyberinfrastructure resources in the paleobiosciences and allied disciplines, with the goal of sharing best practices and protocols among the geoinformatic and bioinformatic communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broad vision for this research is to understand the interactions between the Earth's biological and geophysical systems across all timescales of the Earth's history. This research project established the Earth-Life Consortium (link to http://earthlifeconsortium.org/), which aims to realize this vision by making paleobiological data easily discoverable, accessible, and analyzable. Thus, the specific goals of this research were to 1) Improve and expand the interoperability of cyberinfrastructure within the paleobiological sciences; 2) Promote the sharing and use of paleobiological data within disciplines and with closely allied geoscience and bioscience disciplines; 3) Enhance the sustainability of paleobiological cyberinfrastructure by consolidating smaller resources into larger, community­supported repositories; and 4) Establish a 4D framework for life and its physical environments that spans timescales of years to millennia and extends back to the earliest beginnings of the fossil record.

 

To achieve the goals of this research, a collaborative team of individuals from multiple institutions is working together to 1) establish harmonized Web Application Programming Interfaces and Web services between two databases (the Neotoma Paleoecology Database and the Paleobiology Database (PBDB)), enabling users to jointly query and obtain paleobiological data from both resources; 2) incorporate other databases into Neotoma (in particular, three databases focused on mammals across the America (Miocene Mammal Mapping Project, Mexican Quaternary Mammals Database (MQMD), Antigua Extinction Database) and a Pliocene ostracode database), employing a common database structure and a distributed governance approach based on virtual constituent databases; 3) establish a common data interchange standard between these resources and contemporary biodiversity databases by adopting the DarwinCore format and exporting data from Neotoma and PBDB to this common format; 4) build open­source toolkits for passing Earth-Life Consortium paleodata into R, the open­source scientific and statistical programming language, and creating a clearinghouse for sharing analytical tools developed by the broader community; 5) establish a Paleobiology Data Advisory Council composed of scientists and information specialists from both the geosciences and biosciences; and 6) employ a combination of social media platforms, webinars, and town halls at major meetings to maintain a broad­based and ongoing conversation with the geoscience community about the development, integration, and use of these resources.

 

The outcome of funding to UC Merced for this research focused on Goals 2 and 3. For Goal 2, to promote the sharing and use of paleobiological data within discipline and with closely allied geoscience and bioscience disciplines, PI Blois helped write a manuscript describing the Neotoma Paleoecology Database and its mission as a community-curated data resource that enables broad-scale studies of species and community dynamics during large periods of environmental change. She also gave a series of presentations and workshops about paleoecoinformatics and the role of community-curated data resources for enabling broad-scale, integrative science For Goal 3, to enhance the sustainability of paleobiological CI by consolidating smaller resources into larger, community­supported repositories, PI Blois worked to ingest two primary databases into Neotoma (Antigua, MQMD). Data from Antigua are awaiting final upload and work on MQMD is ongoing.

 

In the course of completing this research, this project supported the training and research of two early career scientists at the University of California, Merced: one of them a woman in a STEM field (Danaan DeNeve Weeks, PhD candidate in Quantitative and Systems Biology) and one a first-generation college student (John Eric Williams, a PhD candidate in Environmental Systems). We held training workshops for Neotoma data users and data stewards that included information about querying amongst different databases, gave presentations about paleoecoinformatics and the role of community-curated data resources for enabling broad-scale, integrative science, and made all of our resources publicly available through GitHub, websites, and newly developed R packages.
